title-group.article-title: Primary Breast Amyloidosis Presenting Solely as Nonpalpable Microcalcifications
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report With Review of the Literature

article-meta.aff: 1Institut de Pathologie et Génétique (IPG), Gosselies, Belgium

author-notes.corresp: Placide Ngendahayo, Institut de Pathologie et Génétique (IPG), Rue Georges Lemaitre 25, Gosselies 6041, Belgium Email: placide.ngendahayo@ipg.be

abstract.p: Primary breast amyloidosis is a rare disease and usually occurs as unilateral or bilateral palpable masses. Primary breast amyloidosis presenting solely as microcalcifications is extremely rare. The authors report a case of a 73-year-old woman with persistent suspicious microcalcifications without palpable mass. The diagnosis was established by the presence of an amorphous and eosinophilic material that was positive for Congo red and dichroic under polarized light. Paraffin immunohistochemistry revealed the presence of kappa light chains (AL-type amyloidosis). The amyloid deposits were associated with microcalcifications. A complete work up was performed to exclude other localisations or associated pathologies and was negative. The primary breast amyloidosis is discussed and a review of the literature is presented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Primary breast amyloidosis is a rare disease and most cases present as unilateral or bilateral palpable masses.1-6 Primary breast amyloidosis presenting solely as nonpalpable microcalcifications is extremely rare and very few cases have been reported up to now.7-10 In this report, we describe the radiological and pathological features of a case of primary breast amyloidosis presenting as nonpalpable microcalcifications and occurring in a 73-year-old woman.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 73-year-old woman presented herself to the radiology department for a screening mammogram. The patient’s history was uneventful and her physical examination was within normal limits. On mammography, the right breast was unremarkable. However, the mammogram of the left breast revealed the presence, in the upper external quadrant, of 2 foci of linear microcalcifications, very suspicious for malignancy.

Multiple needle core biopsies were therefore performed. A complete workup was performed to exclude other localizations or associated pathologies and was negative. A lumpectomy was performed, which showed the same pathological features as the needle core biopsies.
The patient is free of disease 8 years after the excision.

sec.title: Pathological Findings
sec.p: The pathological findings reported are based on the initial needle core biopsies. Nineteen core biopsies 0.3 to 2.0 cm long were received. The microscopic examination disclosed the presence of an amorphous, homogenous, and eosinophilic material (Figures 1-3) in the interstitial tissue (fibrous and fatty tissue) and, to a lesser extent, around ducts, which was positive for Congo red and dichroic under polarized light (Figure 4). Orceine stain was done to exclude an elastotic reaction, especially in periductal location, and was negative (Figure 5).

caption.p: Amyloid deposits in interstitial fibrous tissue

sec.p: Numerous microcalcifications were found within the deposits (Figure 6). Paraffin immunohistochemistry revealed the presence of kappa light chains (Figure 7) and the absence of amyloid A protein.

caption.p: Strong positivity of the deposits for kappa light chains

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Primary breast amyloidosis is an unusual disease. Amyloid deposition in the breast may occur in 2 forms: (a) breast involvement in systemic disease as reported in primary amyloidosis4,6 or in association with malignant or nonmalignant diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis,5 Sjögren syndrome,11,12 multiple myeloma, malignant non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas,1,6,11,13,14 and invasive ductal15-17 or lobular16,18 carcinoma and (b) the localized primary form.3,7,9,10,19-21 The localized primary amyloidosis usually occurs as unilateral or bilateral masses, which frequently simulate carcinoma.3,4,22

Primary breast amyloidosis presenting solely as nonpalpable microcalcifications is extremely rare and very few cases have been reported.7-10 The microcalcifications are frequently described as linear, branching and, as in our case, very suspicious for carcinoma.7-10 The amyloid fibril proteins deposited in breast have been classified as AA amyloid fibril proteins5 or as immunoglobulin of light chain origin,4,6,23 kappa light chain being more frequently found than lambda light chain.6,16,23 In our case, the amyloid proteins were also of immunoglobulin kappa light chain origin despite the fact that the patient had no associated immunological disorder or lymphoid malignancy.

In summary, we report here one more case of breast amyloidosis presenting solely as nonpalpable microcalcifications, occurring in 73-year-old woman, without other localizations or associated pathologies and with deposition of immunoglobulin kappa light amyloid fibrils.
The potential occurrence of amyloidosis should be recognized in the differential diagnosis of breast microcalcifications.
